newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt's ABC says earnings on target.
newsitem.headline: Egypt's ABC says earnings on target.

text.p: Egypt's sole brewer, al-Ahram Beverages/ABC, said on Tuesday it was steadily making up the production shortfall it inherited when the new managers bought the firm from the state on February 18.

At a presentation for international investors 100 days after privatisation, the company said it expected to meet its financial year 1997 earnings estimates despite the shortfall, to be followed in 1998 by a substantial increase in profits.

It did not give its own estimates but it quoted consensus figures of 11.3 pounds ($3.33) per share for 1997 and 13.1 pounds for 1998, averaged from separate estimates by HSBC, Nomura and UBS. The company has 4.5 million shares.

"We expect to meet fiscal 1997 earnings estimates although the government (public-sector company) budget did not foresee the installation of new lines during the peak season... We are projecting substantial increase in profitability for fiscal 1998," a company statement said.
The shares were trading on the Egyptian stock exchange on Tuesday at 129.26 pounds and global depositary receipts, equivalent to half a share, on international markets at $20.

Reporters were excluded from the detailed financial presentation but the figures made available showed that between March 1 and June 15 sales of beer were 1.9 percent above the old government target for the period and sales of non-alcoholic beer 18 percent above the target.
The shortfall inherited was 45,000 hectolitres of alcoholic and non-alcoholic beer and the company has made up more than 8,000 hectolitres since privatisation, the figures showed.
ABC executives said a newly recruited sales force of 30 people had targeted the Cairo area and this is where the initial sales drive has had most impact.
The company says its strategy is to increase profitability by finding new customers and retail outlets which the old public-sector company ignored.
It says one priority is to consolidate its dominance of the market before two potential competitors start producing beer.
Bruce Blackwell, vice-president for sales and distribution, said his sales team had found that of over 12,000 accounts in the Cairo area only 534 were selling the company's beer.
"We've got an incredible opportunity in alcohol," he said.

The new management team is led by Ahmed Zayat of the Luxor Group, a private U.S. company. ABC has brought in technical experts from Danbrew, the technical consulting arm of the Danish brewer Carlsberg.
